questions.question: Deposition of which of the following is responsible for band-shaped keratopathy?
A patient was with the given finding has been having painless and slowly progressive visionloss for the past 10 years. Which of the following diseases is not associated with the givencondition?
questions.explanation: 167Based on the given clinical scenario and ocular finding depicted here, it is suggestive ofband-shaped keratopathy, and systemic lupus erythematosus is not associated with thiscondition.Band-shaped keratopathy (BSK) is due to calcium deposition, primarily in the form ofhydroxyapatite, in the epithelial basement membrane, Bowman's layer, and the anterior stroma.Initially, these deposits are grey but may become chalky-white as the degeneration progresses.It typically presents as a band-shaped opacity in the interpalpebral zone with a clear intervalbetween the ends of the band and the limbus. The condition begins at the periphery and graduallyprogresses towards the centre. The surface of this opaque band is stippled due to holes in thecalcium plaques in the area of nerve canals of Bowman's membrane.Causes of band-shaped keratopathy include local causes such as chronic ocular irritation orinflammatory conditions and systemic diseases that elevate serum calcium levels:Treatment:••Medical management- Chelation using topical ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) 1.5–3.0%Surgical management- Photorefractive keratectomy (PRK) using excimer laser or manualsuperficial keratectomyLocal causesChronic anterior uveitis (especially inJuvenile Idiopathic Arthritis) Interstitial keratitisSuperficial keratitisPhthisis bulbiEnd-stage glaucomaSilicone oil left in the aphakic eyeSystemic diseasesHyperparathyroidismSarcoidosis Multiple myelomaHypophosphatemiaPaget diseaseChronic renal failure

questions.question: 156A 64-year-old woman was brought by her son, during a cataract outreach camp. She gives ahistory of trauma to her left eye, one year back and a complete loss of vision in that eye sincethen. Her image is given below. Which of the following statement is true about her condition?DAILYROUNDS

options.A: Corneal tattooing is a treatment option in this lady.
options.B: The given lesion is an adherent leucoma.
options.C: It is due to scars involving Bowman's layer and superficial stroma.
options.D: Excimer laser phototherapeutic keratectomy is the current treatment of choice.

questions.explanation: The above image shows a dense white opacity, which results from the scarring of more than halfof the stroma, characteristic of leucoma.Corneal tattooing is a treatment option in patients with corneal opacities, who have lost theirvision or who do not expect to recover it. It improves cosmetic appearance by altering the whitecolour of the opacity and blending it to normal eye colour.Depending on the density, corneal opacities are graded as nebula, macula and leucoma.•Nebular corneal opacity (fog or mist):• Hard-to-see corneal scar, due to superficial scars involving Bowman's layer and superficialstroma.•Slit-lamp detection is required.• A thin, diffuse nebula covering the pupillary area interferes more with vision than the localisedleucoma away from the pupillary area. Nebula produces more discomfort due to blurred image(irregular astigmatism).168• Macular corneal opacity:• Semi-dense opacity that can be seen with proper illumination.• Due to scarring involving about half the corneal stroma.•Leucomatous corneal opacity (leucoma simplex):•White scar that is easily seen just by looking at the eye.• Due to scarring of more than half of the stroma• Adherent leucoma:.• It results when healing occurs after perforation of the cornea with incarceration of irisSecondary changes in corneal opacity which may be seen in long-standing cases include hyalinedegeneration, calcareous degeneration, pigmentation and atheromatous ulceration.Treatment:•Keratoplasty is the treatment of choice in leucomatous corneal opacities.• Optical iridectomy may be performed in cases with central adherent leucomas⚫ Phototherapeutic keratectomy (PTK) performed with excimer laser is useful only in superficial(nebular) corneal opacities.

questions.question: Which of the following conditions is least likely to be associated with bilateral cornealopacities in a neonate?
questions.explanation: Keratoglobus is least likely to be associated with bilateral corneal opacities in a neonate. Here, thecornea is clear.Keratoglobus is a rare noninflammatory, familial disorder marked by generalised thinning andglobular protrusion of the cornea. It can be congenital or acquired. The thinning is usuallygreatest at corneal periphery or midperiphery. It can cause refractive errors, otherwise, cornea isclear, normal angle of anterior chamber, normal intraocular pressure with no optic disc cupping.Intrastromal ring segments and cross-linking can be used for management.Other options:Option B: Birth injuries resulting in Descemet's membrane tears can also cause corneal opacities.Option C: Peter's anomaly, also known as iridocorneal adhesions or keratolenticular adhesions, isa posterior corneal defect with an overlying stromal opacity.Option D: Sclerocornea is a congenital disorder in which the cornea is opaque and resembles thesclera, making the limbus indistinct. The central cornea is clearer than the periphery.

questions.question: What causes neurotrophic keratopathy?
questions.explanation: Neurotrophic keratopathy is caused by trigeminal nerve palsy.169Lesions of the fifth cranial nerve from the trigeminal nucleus to the cornea may lead toabnormalities of the normal corneal sensation and trophic stimulation.Causes:• Varicella-zoster (most common cause)• Herpes simplex keratitis• Trauma• Irradiation to the eye• Aneurysm/stroke• Multiple sclerosisMackie characterized three stages of neurotrophic keratitis.•Stage I is characterized by an irregular corneal surface, which later develops into an easilyrecognized punctate keratitis.•Stage II is characterized by a frank epithelial defect, which is typically associated with mildanterior stromal oedema and inflammation.•Stage III involves stromal melting and occasionally perforation.

questions.question: Paralysis of which of the following nerves is responsible for exposure keratopathy?
questions.explanation: Exposure keratopathy is caused by paralysis of the facial nerve.It is the result of incomplete lid closure (lagophthalmos) resulting in drying of the cornea (despitenormal tear production).Causes:• Neuroparalytic, e.g., facial nerve palsy• Reduced muscle tone as in parkinsonism• Mechanical such as lid scarring•ProptosisNote: Neurotrophic keratopathy is due to loss of trigeminal nerve innervation resulting in partialor complete loss of sensation.

questions.question: Which of the following drugs is least likely to cause the given condition?
questions.explanation: Erythromycin is least likely associated with cornea verticillata/vortex keratopathy, a whorl-likeopacity in corneal epithelium, as shown in the image above.Vortex keratopathy occurs due to corneal deposits in the basal epithelium. They are almost alwaysbilateral and are readily recognisable by their distinct appearance as fine, golden-brown or greyopacities that branch out from a central whorl, usually across the inferior cornea. Opacity due to170drugs is reversible upon stopping the drug.Causes:••Amiodarone (most common) (Option A)• Tamoxifen (Option C)•• Indomethacin• Chloroquine (Option D)●•Chlorpromazine (rarely)Fabry's disease

questions.question: DAILYROUNDS158A 30-year-old albino woman presents with a characteristic finding as shown below. Which ofthe following statements are true regarding the suspected condition?
questions.explanation: A 30-year-old individual with corneal changes, as shown above, known as gerontoxon or arcuslipoides, may require screening for underlying lipid disorder.Arcus senilis (AS), also known as gerontoxon, arcus lipoides or arcus cornealis, is usually anage-related lipid degeneration of the peripheral cornea that forms a light grey or bluish ring. It isthe most common peripheral corneal opacity, typically benign, occurring bilaterally and prevalentamong the elderly.However, when observed in individuals under 50, termed arcus juvenilis, it may indicateunderlying lipid disorder and an increased risk of cardiovascular disease, warranting lipid profilescreening. Unilateral cases of arcus senilis may indicate contralateral carotid artery stenosis dueto decreased ophthalmic blood flow on the ipsilateral side, resulting in protection from formingarcus in the ipsilateral eye.The condition results from the leakage of lipoproteins (phospholipids and cholesterol) from limbalcapillaries into the corneal stroma, initiating deposition at the superior and inferior cornea. Overtime, the ring progresses circumferentially, sparing a clear corneal zone adjacent to the limbuscalled the interval of Vogt.The following opacities and rings can resemble arcus senilis:•Kayser- Fleischer (KF) ring: A dark brown ring caused by the deposition of excess copper inDescemet's membrane, classically seen in Wilson's disease. It may also be seen in certain chronic,cholestatic liver conditions such as primary biliary cirrhosis.• Limbus sign: Caused by dystrophic calcification, seen as a "milky precipitate" at the corneallimbus. It can sometimes be confused with AS in the elderly population.• Pseudo-gerontoxon: A greyish peri-limbal band of superficial scarring adjacent to a previouslyinflamed segment of the limbus resembling AS, seen in vernal keratoconjunctivitis.The image below depicts the Kayser-Fleischer ring and anterior capsule of the crystalline lens(Sunflower cataract) seen in Wilson's disease.171

questions.question: A young male labourer presents to the casualty with severe bilateral eye pain that woke himfrom sleep. He reports welding the previous afternoon without a face shield and symptoms ofphotophobia, blurry vision, tearing, and worsening pain in bright light. Examination revealsmild conjunctival injection and diffuse punctate epithelial erosions on the cornea. What is themost likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The described corneal findings, with his classic history of welding less than 12 hours prior topresentation, are suggestive of photophthalmia.Photophthalmia is produced due to exposure to short-wavelength ultraviolet (UV-B) rays. Thecornea absorbs the majority of UV light (especially 311 to 290 nm). It results in desquamation ofthe epithelium leading to multiple painful corneal erosions. Causes of of UV keratitis:The symptoms appear characteristically after a latent period of 4-5 hours of exposure toultraviolet light. There is intense burning pain, foreign body sensation, and watering of the eyes.There may be associated marked photophobia and blepharospasm. On slit-lamp examination,corneal epithelium shows a breach in continuity and takes up fluorescein stain.Management comprises cold compresses, lubricant eye drops and bandaging eyes for 24 hourswith antibiotic eye ointment and cycloplegic. Avoid local surface topical anaesthesia. Crooke'sglass is a prophylactic aid consisting of a spectacle lens combined with metallic oxides to absorbultraviolet or infrared rays and should be used by those who are prone to exposure.Note: Photoretinitis and macular burns are often a result of infrared radiation.Artificial causesArc weldingFlash from short-circuits, Damaged metal halide lampsTanning bedsUV germicidal lamps.Natural causesExposure to strong solar radiation at high altitudes especially on snow-covered terrain(snow blindness) Prolonged viewing of a solar eclipse without proper eye protection.172

questions.question: Which of the following is a method for long-term preservation of cornea?159
questions.explanation: Cryopreservation is used for long-term preservation of cornea, up to 1 year.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common cause of infection following cornealtransplantation in India?
questions.explanation: Staphylococcus epidermidis is the most common cause of infectious keratitis after cornealtransplantation in developing countries.Pneumococcus spp. and Staphylococcus aureus have been found to be the most common causes ofpost-corneal transplant infections in developed countries.

questions.question: Which of the following techniques is the gold standard for assessing corneal thickness?
questions.explanation: The gold standard technique for assessing corneal thickness is ultrasound pachymetry, whichuses a corneal pachymeter.Measurement of the corneal thickness (pachymetry) indirectly reflects endothelial function. Theaverage central corneal thickness is around 0.5 mm, which gradually increases toward theperiphery to around 0.7 mm. Normally, as a diurnal variation, corneas tend to be slightly thickerjust after a person awakes in the morning.Other options:Option A: Confocal microscopy is an imaging technique that allows in vivo examination of cornealstructures at high magnification and resolution. It is used to assess corneal nerve morphology andcorneal endothelium.Option B: Keratometry measures the anterior corneal curvature and is traditionally performedwith a manual keratometer, also known as an ophthalmometer.Option D: Corneal topography is used to assess the anterior corneal surface, its shape andthickness.The image below shows a corneal pachymeter.173READRECALLPRINT6CO9RESET

questions.question: Your aunt recently shared that it is becoming cumbersome for her to frequently change herglasses. You suggested a referral and the rapid change in power was diagnosed to be due tokeratoconus. The following image shows the results of one of the investigations done on her.What is the name of the investigation?16090.080.07009mm60.050.046.044.042.040.08.036.034.032.030.020.010.0TCurvatureAbs3003403804204605005405806200-660190700740780482021086090010 pmTPachyAbs
questions.explanation: The investigation shown in the image is corneal topography, and it is used for conditions likekeratoconus, as seen in this clinical scenario.Corneal topography captures the shape of the cornea by projecting concentric rings of light ontoits anterior surface, forming a Placido disc pattern. the reflected light is analyzed with specialisedsoftware to create a detailed map of the corneal curvature.•Uses:• Detection of corneal ectasia, mainly keratoconus• To measure corneal thickness●• Prior to refractive surgery•Sometimes prior to contact lens fittingThe image shows a Placido or Keratoscopic disc which is used for corneal surface assessment.174

questions.question: A 20-year-old girl with high myopia was referred by the optometrist for further evaluation.She has a history of recurrent allergic conjunctivitis and persistent eye rubbing. An image isgiven below. Which of the following statements are true about the given condition?
questions.explanation: Keratoconus is a progressive bilateral corneal ectatic disorder. It manifests as characteristiccone-like steepening of the cornea associated with irregular stromal thinning, resulting in acone-like bulge (protrusion) and significant loss of vision.The pathogenesis is not fully known. Several associations have been identified, which include rigidcontact lens wear, chronic eye rubbing, Down's syndrome, atopic disease, Leber's congenitalamaurosis, and connective tissue disease.It is a non-inflammatory disease. With the exception of the significant loss of vision, other classicsigns of inflammation are not usually present. The asymmetrical thinning and the highly irregularcorneal topography often causes significant myopia and irregular astigmatism.Corneal topography is the primary diagnostic tool for KCN detection.Whereas keratoplasty, historically has been the mainstay of treatment for keratoconus, it is nowgenerally reserved for eyes that are unable to achieve functional vision with other surgical ornon-surgical modalities and is only considered only as a last resort, in very advanced disease. It isthe definitive treatment for keratoconus, not the treatment of choice.175Haab'sStriae-CongenitalGlaucomaVogt'sStriae-Keratoconus

questions.question: Which of the following is not a treatment option in advanced keratoconus?
questions.explanation: Vision correction with spectacles with spherical/toric soft contact lenses is suboptimal and onlyapplicable to the early stages of keratoconus, not in the advanced stages.Keratoconus is a progressive, non-inflammatory, bilateral corneal ectasia characterized bycone-like steepening due to irregular stromal thinning. This leads to a conical corneal protrusion,significant vision loss, myopia and irregular astigmatism.The available options for the management of keratoconus are highly dependent on the stage of thedisease and its progression. If the disease is stabilized (no progression), the emphasis is given tocorrecting the vision. If the disease is progressing, the emphasis is on slowing (arresting) theprogression.•Treatment options in moderate-to-advanced keratoconus:Rigid gas-permeable contact lenses and vaulting scleral lenses are the mainstays of visiontreatment for moderate to advanced KCN. Their main advantage is the creation of a tear poolbetween the lens and the cornea, which naturally neutralizes the ocular aberrations associatedwith keratoconus. (Option B and C)• Intra-corneal ring segments (INTACS)- small curved PMMA ring or set of rings that areimplanted in the cornea to help flatten corneal curvature to improve vision.•Corneal transplantation- Deep anterior lamellar keratoplasty (DALK) and penetratingkeratoplasty (PKP)Corneal collagen cross-linking with riboflavin (CXL or C3R) and ultraviolet-A rays arrest theprogression of the disease. (Option D)

questions.question: A 40-year old male with progressive loss of vision in his left eye was diagnosed withagainst-the-rule astigmatism. Examination revealed peripheral corneal thinning, but therewas no inflammation. Which of the following is least likely to be the cause?
questions.explanation: 176The examination in a 40-year-old male revealed peripheral corneal thinning with noinflammation, making peripheral ulcerative keratitis, an inflammatory condition, the least likelycause.Peripheral ulcerative keratitis is a destructive inflammatory disease involving the peripheralcornea. It is associated with signs and symptoms of inflammation. The other options are causes ofperipheral thinning in a quiet eye.Other options:Options A and B: Terrien's and Pellucid marginal degeneration are noninflammatory cornealdegenerations. Pellucid degeneration causes bilateral, inferior corneal thinning that leads tomarked, irregular, against-the-rule astigmatism. Terrien's degeneration usually begins in thesuperior cornea.Option C: Dellen is a localized thinning of the peripheral cornea associated with the drying of afocal area. Usually associated with an adjacent elevated lesion (e.g., pinguecula or a largesubconjunctival haemorrhage) that impairs physiological lubrication.

questions.question: A 47-year-old woman presented with tearing, irritation, and photophobia of the left eye. Onexamination, a paracentral, crescent-shaped corneal melt was noted. Peripheral ulcerativekeratitis (PUK) was suspected. What is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.explanation: Rheumatoid arthritis is commonly associated with peripheral ulcerative keratitis (PUK). It is alsothe most common cause.PUK is a group of destructive inflammatory diseases involving the peripheral cornea,characterized by the sloughing of corneal epithelium and keratolysis (corneal melting). It can leadto corneal perforation. The causes can be divided into:• Infectious-bacterial, viral, protozoal, fungal.• Non-infectious- rheumatoid arthritis, Wegener's granulomatosis, SLE, rosacea, psoriasis etc.Ophthalmologic manifestations of rheumatoid arthritis (due to type III and IV hypersensitivityreactions):•dry eye•⚫ scleritis•• stromal keratitis⚫ peripheral ulcerative keratitis•• paracentral keratolysisTreatment of PUK includes protection of the surface from drying and exposure; systemiccorticosteroids and immunomodulatory; use of adjuncts such as amniotic membrane grafts topromote healing; and in some situations, tectonic keratoplasty.

questions.question: 162A 54-year-old school teacher presented with a chief complaint of pain in the eyes andintermittent blurry vision which was worse in the mornings. Generalized corneal haze wasnoted in both eyes but was more significant in the left. Examination findings are given below.What is the likely diagnosis?AB
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario along with beaten metal appearance on slit lamp and reducedendothelial cell density with coalescing guttata on specular microscopy is suggestive of Fuch's177endothelial dystrophy.Fuchs endothelial dystrophy is a bilateral, slowly progressive, often asymmetric corneal disease. Itis characterized by deterioration of endothelial cells and development of guttata, which areexcrescences of Descemet's membrane (seen on specular or confocal microscopy). Females areaffected more than males. It is more common in the 4th decade or later.Endothelial layer dysfunction causes loss of corneal deturgescence, and bilateral oedema of thestroma, leading to ocular pain, glare, halos, and decreased visual acuity. Patients have a worsevision in the morning because of the eyes being closed during the night causing a buildup ofcorneal oedema.•Stages of Fuch's endothelial dystrophy:••Stage 1: Central corneal guttata that spreads peripherallyStage 2: Corneal oedema - beaten metal-like appearanceStage 3: Bullous keratopathy• Stage 4: Subepithelial scarring and superficial vascularizationTreatment:•Conservative option- topical hypertonic (saline sodium chloride 5% drops or 6% ointment) andbandage contact lenses.• The definitive treatment is endothelial keratoplasty: Descemet's stripping endothelialkeratoplasty (DSEK/DSAEK) or Descemet membrane Endothelial keratoplasty (DMEK).

questions.question: Which of the following is not true about macular corneal dystrophy?
questions.explanation: Macular dystrophy does not spare the peripheral cornea.It is the least common corneal dystrophy. It has an autosomal recessive inheritance. Most othercorneal dystrophies are autosomal dominant. It is associated with mucopolysaccharidoses and ischaracterized by the deposition of glycosaminoglycans in the stroma and staining by Alcian blue.It develops in childhood and is progressive, resulting in profound visual impairment in early adultlife.Clinical examination reveals superficial whitish fleck-like opacities. These opacities extendperipherally to the limbus and the deep stroma down to Descemet's membrane. The interveningcorneal stroma develops a progressive and diffuse haze.Note:• Most common dystrophy overall- Microcystic/fingerprint/map-dot dystrophy•• Most common stromal dystrophy- Lattice dystrophy• Dystrophy with corectopia- Posterior polymorphous dystrophy• Autosomal recessive dystrophy- Macular dystrophy178

questions.question: Which of the following stains is used in identifying granular dystrophy of the cornea?
questions.explanation: Masson trichrome stains stromal hyaline deposits in granular dystrophy of the cornea.Granular corneal dystrophy belongs to the stromal dystrophy of the cornea. It is of autosomaldominant inheritance and is caused by a defect in the TGFB1 gene.Granular corneal dystrophy is characterized by milky, granular, hyaline deposits in the anteriorstroma, which may coalesce into irregular shapes. The peripheral cornea and the area between theopacities/deposits remain clear. Early symptoms may involve light sensitivity, glare, oculardiscomfort, pain, and watering. As opacification progresses with age, visual acuity decreases.The following image shows numerous irregularly shaped discrete crumb-like corneal opacities ofGranular dystrophy, which stain bright red with Masson trichrome.

questions.question: Which of the following is implicated in the pathogenesis of oil-droplet keratopathy?

options.A: Deposition of lipid in the anterior stroma

questions.explanation: Oil-droplet keratopathy occurs due to exposure to ultraviolet (UV) rays.Climatic droplet keratopathy (CDK), alternatively known as oil droplet keratopathy/spheroidaldegeneration/Labrador keratopathy, is an acquired corneal degenerative disorder. Clumps ofvariably sized golden-yellow globules accumulate in the superficial corneal stroma and arethought to be derived from photochemical degradation of plasma proteins, by UV radiation.The image shows Labrador keratopathy.179Other options:Option A: Lipid keratopathy involves the accumulation of whitish or yellow fat deposits, mainlycholesterol and fatty acids, which begin intracellularly and later move extracellularly due tonecrosis of corneal stromal cells. It can be primary (rare, in the cornea free of vascularization) orsecondary (common, in the vascularized cornea).Option C: Exposure keratopathy results from lagophthalmos (incomplete eyelid closure), causingcorneal dryness despite normal tear production. Causes include neuroparalytic conditions (likefacial nerve palsy), reduced muscle tone in Parkinsonism, lid scarring, post-blepharoplasty andproptosis.Option D: Neurotrophic keratopathy results from loss of trigeminal nerve innervation to thecornea, affecting both sensation and healing. This disruption can cause corneal dryness,ulceration, exfoliation, and edema. It is commonly linked to conditions such as trigeminalganglion surgical ablation for neuralgia, stroke, diabetes, herpes simplex and herpes zosterkeratitis.

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding intracorneal ring segment (ICRS) implantation isfalse?

options.B: It is used in the management of keratoconus.
options.C: Corneal perforation is a very common complication.
options.D: It is made of polymethyl methacrylate.

questions.explanation: Corneal perforation may occur but is quite rare in intracorneal ring segment (ICRS) implantation.Salient points on ICRS:•• These segments are made of polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA) and are implanted into themid-peripheral corneal stroma.•.These are used in the management of keratoconus and low myopia.Improvement in visual acuity and refraction after ICRS implantation is accomplished by ashortening of collagen lamellae along the arc length of the ring. There is a redistribution ofcorneal stress due to a change in the curvature of the cornea after implantation of the ICRS.• Decreased corneal sensation can be a postoperative complication.180•More than 90% of patients have <1 D change in refraction at 1-year postoperative follow-up.The image shows the intrastromal corneal ring segment.

questions.question: A 29-year-old woman with normal visual acuity undergoes a routine eye exam. Slit-lampexamination reveals numerous crumb-like centrally dense deposits in the anterior cornealstroma, bilaterally symmetrical, with clear intervening stroma. Which of the followingstatements is likely to be true?164

options.A: Histopathology specimen will stain positive with alcian blue
options.B: Histopathologic review will reveal amyloid deposits on congo red staining
options.C: Histopathologic review will reveal hyaline deposits on the Masson trichrome stain

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario, with the given image showing multiple breadcrumb-like deposits, issuggestive of granular corneal dystrophy, where histopathology reveals hyaline deposits on theMasson trichrome stain.Granular corneal dystrophy belongs to the stromal dystrophy of the cornea. It is of autosomaldominant inheritance and is caused by a defect in the TGFB1 gene.In granular corneal dystrophy, opacities form due to the abnormal accumulation of hyalineprotein, assuming a discrete granular form and subsequently coalescing into various irregularshapes. The cornea between the opacities and the peripheral cornea remains clear. The conditionis characterised by milky granular hyaline deposits in the anterior stroma.In many patients, no symptoms occur, whereas some patients develop recurrent erosions. In thefifth decade or later, some patients develop sufficient visual difficulties to require keratoplasty.Treatment is usually keratoplasty for severe visual handicaps.Note: The beaten metal appearance on the slit lamp and reduced endothelial cell density withcoalescing guttata on specular microscopy is suggestive of Fuch's endothelial dystrophy.

questions.question: A 6-month-old infant is brought with a history of diffuse, ground glass-like corneal haze inboth eyes. The corneas are thickened with normal diameters and associated nystagmus.Which one of the following statements is true regarding this condition?

options.A: Intraocular pressure (IOP) is likely to be elevated.
options.B: The corneal stroma shows abnormal deposits that stain with amyloid.
options.C: It could be a bilateral choristoma.
options.D: Descemet's membrane may be thickened due to an abnormal endothelium.

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario most likely suggest congenital hereditary endothelial dystrophy(CHED), where Descemet's membrane is abnormally thickened.CHED is a rare disorder characterized by focal or diffuse thickening of the Descemet membraneand endothelial degeneration. The key features of this condition include corneal thickness, which181is two to three times the normal, normal intraocular pressure (IOP) and normal corneal diameter.Associated features are corneal pannus, nystagmus, and esotropia.Treatment usually involves corneal transplantation (lamellar or penetrating keratoplasty) forvisual rehabilitation.Other options:Option A: As the corneal diameters are normal, and there are no typical symptoms, congenitalglaucoma is ruled out.Option B: Amyloid deposits in the corneal stroma are seen in Lattice stromal dystrophy.Option C: Choristomas are congenital lesions representing normal tissue(s) in an abnormallocation. They are the most common epibulbar and orbital tumors in children. It usually arises atthe limbus of the eye and may include dermoid tissue, lipodermoid or other tissues.Note: The combination of congenital endothelial dystrophy and progressive neural deafness, isknown as Harboyan syndrome. This disorder must be distinguished from another autosomalrecessive disorder, congenital endothelial dystrophy, in which deafness does not occur.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true about Mooren's ulcer?

options.A: Painless superficial ulcer that can perforate
options.B: Associated with autoimmune and rheumatological conditions
options.C: Characterized by a steep, overhanging edge
options.D: Ulcerative process begins centrally and then moves circumferentially165

questions.explanation: Moorens's ulcer/ulcus roden is characterized by a steep, overhanging edge.It is described as a chronic serpiginous ulcer of the cornea. It is a subtype of peripheral ulcerativekeratitis (PUK). It is defined as an idiopathic condition without associated systemic orrheumatological conditions and hence is a diagnosis of exclusion. The pathophysiology is thoughtto be due to autoimmune.Clinical features include redness, tearing, and photophobia, but pain is typically the outstandingfeature. The pain often is incapacitating and may well be out of proportion to the inflammation.There may also be a complaint of decreased visual acuity, which may be secondary to associatediritis or central corneal involvement.Initially, the ulcerative process spreads circumferentially. Later, it moves centrally to involve theentire cornea. In contrast to other forms of PUK, the limbus is involved. The end-stage result istypically a scarred, vascularized cornea that may be thinned to less than half of its originalthickness.Treatment involves corticosteroids and excision of a strip of adjacent conjunctiva, whicheliminates the conjunctival sources of collagenase and proteoglycanase.The image shows a perforated Mooren's ulcer.182

questions.question: Which layer of the cornea is affected in Reis-Buckler dystrophy?
questions.explanation: The corneal layer involved in Reis-Buckler dystrophy is Bowman's membrane.Corneal dystrophies are primarily a bilateral, inherited, non-inflammatory condition specific tothe cornea.Reis-Buckler dystrophy, an autosomal dominant disorder, is an anterior variant of granularstromal dystrophy, characterised by the replacement of the Bowman layer with connective tissuebands, primarily affecting the Bowman layer and superficial stroma. Several recurrent cornealerosions may occur in childhood along with visual impairment.In this condition, there are grey-white, geographic subepithelial opacities (that are most densecentrally and increase over time, eventually forming a reticular pattern. Additionally, cornealsensation is reduced as the disease progresses.The image below shows Reis-buckler corneal dystrophy on slit-lamp examination:183184

questions.question: Detailed ExplanationsBand-shaped keratopathy is caused by pathological calcium deposition on the cornea in the formof a band.On exam, there is a white band-like formation of calcium across the corneal surface with irregularborders and a peripheral clearing of cornea between the calcium deposits and the limbus. Thecalcium deposition is typically found beneath the epithelial layer within Bowman's layer but mayextend into the anterior stroma.Once the visual axis starts to get involved, there will be progressive loss of vision. Recurrence iscommon unless the predisposing cause is identified and treated.Local causes such as chronic ocular irritation or inflammatory conditions and systemicdiseases that elevate serum calcium levels are the main causes for band-shaped keratopathy. Itcan rarely have hereditary causes as well.Image given below shows band-shaped keratopathy.Solution to Question 2:167Based on the given clinical scenario and ocular finding depicted here, it is suggestive ofband-shaped keratopathy, and systemic lupus erythematosus is not associated with thiscondition.Band-shaped keratopathy (BSK) is due to calcium deposition, primarily in the form ofhydroxyapatite, in the epithelial basement membrane, Bowman's layer, and the anterior stroma.Initially, these deposits are grey but may become chalky-white as the degeneration progresses.It typically presents as a band-shaped opacity in the interpalpebral zone with a clear intervalbetween the ends of the band and the limbus.
